PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
1.  During the country programming mission held in Manila in November 2011, the Government 
of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to assist 
Henan provincial government (HPG) in preparing the Henan Value Chain and Products Safety 
Demonstration Project (the project), which is included in ADB’s lending program for 2015. Although 
the HPG has experience with ADB’s project preparation, it is still necessary to provide a project 
preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) to help HPG prepare the project in compliance with ADB’s 
requirements and with best international practices in the project design. 
 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
 
2.  The PPTA will (i) assess the project's technical, economic, and financial feasibility; (ii) assess 
safeguards  requirements;  (iii)  conduct  social  survey  and  consultations  for  poverty,  social,  and 
gender analysis; (iv) prepare project documents according to ADB’s requirements; (v) assist the 
HPG in revising domestic feasibility studies and improving safeguard documents in line with ADB's 
and the government's requirements; and (vi) conduct training and capacity development. The key 
outputs and activities are summarized in Table A4.1.

C .  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement

fr om Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The HPG will provide counterpart 
support in the form of counterpart staff, office space, facilities, supplies, and transportation. The

D.  Consulting Services 
 
4.  The PPTA will require services of 14.5 person-months (pm) of international and 23.5 pm of 
national consultants. A consulting firm will be recruited through quality- and cost-based selection 
method using a quality-cost ratio of 80:20 and simplified technical proposal according to ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). Table A4.3 provides 
details of the consultant requirements. The outline terms of reference for the PPTA consultants are 
described in paras. 5–12. Master’s degrees and/or equivalent experience in relevant disciplines or 
equivalent are required for all international and national consultants unless indicated otherwise. All 
international consultants are required to have at least 10 years and for national consultants at least 
five years relevant work experience.

5.  Economic  and  financial  specialists  and  team  leader  and  deputy  team  leader 
(international,  4  pm;  national,  6  pm).  Each  specialist  will  have  at  least  a  master’s  degree  in

Appendix 4  3 
agricultural  economics, finance  or  a  relevant  discipline,  and  work  experience  in  economic  and 
financial analysis of investment projects. The national specialist will be the deputy team leader. The 
specialists will (i) assess the macroeconomic and the sector contexts, (ii) assess demands of goods 
under by the project, (iii) identify and establish economic rationale of the public sector involvement, 
(iv) assess a least-cost investment option to achieve the project objective, (v) undertake project 
economic cost-benefit analysis, (vi) assess financial and institutional sustainability, (vii) undertake a 
distribution analysis, (viii) assess project participating enterprise’s (PPE’s) financial performance and 
position based on the recent audited (non-audited if not available) financial statements using key 
operating and financial ratios, (ix) prepare project cost estimates, (x) assess the impact of the project 
on  PPE’s financial  performance  and  position over  time,  and  (xi) undertake  sensitivity  and  risk 
analyses. The specialist will prepare project cost estimates and financing plan. 
 
6.  Livestock  farming  system  specialists  (international,  2.0  pm;  national,  2.5  pm).  The 
international specialist will also be the team leader. Each specialist will have at least a master’s 
degree in livestock production or a relevant discipline, and work experience in commercial livestock 
production and product traceability. For each PPE, the specialists will (i) assess existing livestock 
production and processing system and their subproject proposals and identify weaknesses and 
opportunities  for  improvement;  (ii)  prepare  a  report  that  describes  findings  of  (i)  and 
recommendations to strengthen the livestock husbandry and whole-of-cycle processing; (iii) ensure 
those  recommendations  be  reflected  in  subproject  design;  (iv)  prepare  a  training  program  on 
livestock production and processing tailored to the specific needs, capacity, and requirements; and 
(v) prepare all the reports required by ADB, including inception, interim, draft final, and final reports 
and a draft RRP and its linked documents in cooperation with other team members. 
 
7.  Food safety specialists (international, 3 pm; national, 3 pm). Each specialist will have a 
master’s degree in food and/or dairy science, biology, or a relevant discipline; and work experience 
in food safety, particularly, the hazard analysis and critical control points-controlled food processing 
systems. The specialists, in cooperation with the quality monitoring and supervision center of Henan 
husbandry bureau, will (i) assess the existing food safety monitoring and control system of the 
provincial  and  local  governments  and  PPEs;  (ii)  assess  the  proposed  investments  of  the 
governments and PPEs for project output 1 (i.e., product safety monitoring capacity); (iii) finalize 
investments of the governments and PPEs for the output and relevant training program; and (iv) 
organize workshops and implement training to develop capacity of the relevant government offices 
and PPEs. 
 
8.  Environment specialists (international, 3 pm; national, 4 pm). Each specialist will have a 
master’s  degree  in  environmental  studies  or  a  relevant  discipline,  and  work  experience  in 
environmental assessment. The specialists will (i) assess possible environmental impacts of the 
project as a whole and of each subproject; and (ii) prepare an initial environmental examination, 
including an environmental management plan, which will be tailored to the site-specific conditions of 
each PPE. 
 
9.  Social development specialists (international, 2.5 pm; national, 3.0 pm). Each specialist 
will have a master’s degree in social sciences, development studies, or a relevant discipline; and 
work  experience  in  social  and  gender  development,  preferably  with  international  financial 
institutions. For project and each subproject, the specialists will (i) conduct a poverty and social 
analysis  with  particular  attention  to  poverty  and  vulnerability,  gender,  inclusion,  and  labor  and 
employment; (ii) prepare a consultation and participation plan, a social action plan, and a gender 
action plan; and (iii) confirm that there are no impacts on ethnic minorities. 
 
10.  Resettlement specialist (national, 1 pm). The specialist will have a master’s degree in 
social sciences, development studies, or a relevant discipline; and work experience in resettlement, 
preferably with international financial institutions. For project and each subproject, the specialist will 
(i) collect data on land use by the PPEs in project impact areas, and assess whether any land

acquisition was done in the last five years in anticipation of the project; and if so, conduct due 
diligence in accordance with safeguard requirements 2 of ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009) 
and (ii) assist HPG in proposing corrective action plan(s) for subproject(s) if needed. 
 
11.  Financial management specialist (national, 2 pm). The specialist will have a bachelor’s 
degree in financial management or relevant discipline, a professional accountancy qualification, and 
work  experience  in  project  financial  management  assessment  of  ADB  or  other  international 
development banks. The specialist will (i) conduct financial management assessments of HPG, 11 
project municipal and 16 county governments, and 16 PPEs; (ii) propose an appropriate fund flow 
design  and  disbursement  mechanisms  and  training  requirements  for  financial  management  as 
necessary based on the assessments; and (iii) summarize (i) and (ii) in a standalone report. 
 
12.  Procurement  specialist  (national, 2 pm). The specialist will have  at least 7-year work 
experience with procurement and consultant recruitment for ADB and/or other externally-funded 
projects.  The  specialist  will  (i)  assess  procurement  and  consultant  recruitment  capacity  of  the 
executing agency and procurement capacity of the implementing agencies; and (ii) prepare and 
update a procurement plan that will contain a list all packages for procurement of works and goods 
and recruitment of consultants envisaged under the project. 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  HPG will be the executing agency for the PPTA. Implementing agencies will be 11 municipal 
and 16 county governments where the proposed PPEs are located, and the livestock product quality 
control and inspection center under Henan animal husbandry bureau. The project management 
office  established  at  the  foreign  economic  center  of  Henan  agriculture  department  will  be 
responsible for PPTA implementation and coordination with ADB and the implementing agencies. 
Disbursement will be carried out following ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook 
(2010, as amended from time to time). Procurement of equipment will follow ADB’s Procurement 
Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time), and will be turned over to the executing agency 
upon  the  PPTA  completion.  The  PPTA  is  expected  to  commence  on  15  June  2013  and  be 
completed  on  31  May  2014.  The  proposed  PPTA  processing  and  implementation  schedule  is 
provided in Table A4.4. 
 
Table A4.4: Technical Assistance Processing and Implementation Schedule 
Major Milestones  Expected Completion Date

* Inception, midterm, and draft final reports will be submitted at least 1 week prior to the respective missions. 
Source: Asian Development Bank estimates.
